title: English (1770) Worsley New Testament (Print)
description:
The 1770 Worsley New Testament is a notable translation of the New Testament by John Worsley, printed in London by R. Hett. Titled "The New Testament or New Covenant of Our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ," this translation was distinctive for its approach to aligning the text with the idiom of the English language of that time. Worsley's work aimed to provide a translation that was both faithful to the Greek original and comprehensible in contemporary English.

One of the unique features of Worsley's New Testament is the inclusion of notes and references throughout the text. These annotations were interspersed as needed to confirm and illustrate the translation choices made, particularly where literal or varying renderings were presented at the bottom of each page. This aspect of the translation was designed to enable even those who were not familiar with the original Greek to understand and appreciate the accuracy and appropriateness of Worsley's translation.

Worsley's translation reflects the evolving nature of biblical scholarship and translation in the 18th century. By focusing on the idiom and vernacular of the English language of his time, Worsley contributed to making the New Testament more accessible and relatable to the contemporary audience. His work remains an interesting example of the dynamic and interpretive nature of Bible translation.
